title: Antony Andrewes
text:
Antony Andrewes, (12 June 1910 – 13 June 1990) was an English classical scholar and historian. He was <a href="Wykeham%20Professor%20of%20Ancient%20History">Wykeham Professor of Ancient History</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a> from 1953 to 1977.
Early life.
Andrewes was born in <a href="Tavistock%2C%20Devon">Tavistock</a>, <a href="Devon">Devon</a>, England, on 12 June 1910. He was educated at <a href="Winchester%20College">Winchester College</a> from 1923 to 1929. He studied at <a href="New%20College%2C%20Oxford">New College, Oxford</a>, between 1929 and 1933.
Career.
Academic career.
Andrewes was a Fellow of <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Oxford">Pembroke College, Oxford</a>, between 1933 and 1946, and of <a href="New%20College%2C%20Oxford">New College, Oxford</a>, from 1946 to 1953. He was Wykeham Professor of Ancient History from 1953 until his retirement in 1977.
Military service.
On 20 June 1941, he was <a href="commissioned%20officer">commissioned</a> in the <a href="Intelligence%20Corps%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Intelligence Corps</a>, <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a>, as a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a>. His <a href="service%20number">service number</a> was 191239. By January 1945, he was a <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> (<a href="temporary%20rank">temporary</a> <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>).
Later life.
He died in 1990, the day after his 80th birthday.
Honours.
On 4 January 1945, Andrewes was appointed Member of the military division of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) 'in recognition of gallant and distinguished service in the field'. He was elected a <a href="Fellow%20of%20the%20British%20Academy">Fellow of the British Academy</a> in 1957.
